comment.author: 53531067@N05
comment._content: Beautiful old image of the church. It Looks very  romantic!

comment.author: 73327671@N02
comment._content: Wherever this is, it isn't St Ouen. Look at old (and modern) photographs of St Ouen and you'll see that it's taller and the design of the triforium and apse quite different. Besides, S Ouen still has all (I think) of its medieval stained glass, and also its 1890 Cavaillé-Coll organ and was never in such a ruinous state. Furthermore, I'm not sure about the date 1910 - unless this building was ruined in the Revolution, it would have to have been ruined in the war of 1914-18. That is unless there were churches ruined in the Franco-Prussian war...

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi Richard, 
We'll take a look at the label on actual image and make sure that we transcribed it correctly. There are also quite a few other S. Ouen images in the collection that we can compare this to and see if it matches. Then some historical research ay be in order. This may take a while, but we'll get back to you when we have some more info to offer.
Thanks for the comment (I love a puzzle)!
Deb Wythe
Digital Lab

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi Richard,
Well, it took us a while, but our Archivist did the research and identified this image  and several others as  Abbey of Notre Dame (Oise), Chiry-Ourscamp, not  St. Ouen, Rouen, as ID'd on the original photos. I'm finally updating them -- many thanks for giving us the heads up on this.
Deb Wythe
Digital Lab
